keyTakeAways: Seven universities have formally rejected a White House funding compact that ties federal research funding to ideological policy changes.
The compact includes demands such as removing sex and ethnicity from admissions, capping international enrollment at 15%, and enforcing annual anonymous polls to assess compliance.
Universities argue that such mandates threaten academic freedom, institutional autonomy, and merit-based research funding.
The White House claims the compact promotes a 'vibrant marketplace of ideas' and offers priority in federal grants and access to White House events.
Universities like MIT, Penn, Brown, USC, Dartmouth, UVA, and the University of Arizona have publicly rejected the proposal, citing threats to academic independence.
The Trump administration has previously increased lobbying efforts by targeted universities, indicating a strategic push to influence higher education policy.
The University of Texas at Austin is the only school that has not rejected the offer, choosing instead to welcome the opportunity and engage in dialogue.
A copy of the compact was drafted in December 2024, with edits made during the president’s return to office, showing evolving policy direction.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Seven universities, including the University of Arizona, University of Virginia, MIT, Penn, USC, Dartmouth, and Brown, have rejected a White House funding proposal that offers expanded access to federal research grants in exchange for significant ideological policy changes. These demands include eliminating sex and ethnicity from admissions, capping international student enrollment at 15%, enforcing annual anonymous compliance polls, and adopting specific biological definitions of gender. The universities argue that such mandates threaten academic freedom, institutional autonomy, and merit-based competition, which are essential to innovation and excellence in higher education. The White House claims the compact promotes a diverse 'marketplace of ideas' and provides a competitive advantage through prioritized funding and access to events. While some institutions like the University of Texas at Austin remain open to dialogue, others have firmly rejected the proposal, citing threats to their core mission. The compact, which was drafted in December 2024 and initially sent to nine universities, has now expanded to include three additional schools, with a deadline of November 21, 2025, for initial signatories.
title: Seven Universities Reject White House Funding Deal with Attached Demands
